results.title: Gender and relationships
results.creator_credit: Carol Trussell and Coastline Community College
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Psychology: the study of human behavior”.
Close relationships help us achieve fulfilment as human beings. What do we expect from them and how do they change as we change? This program looks at the dynamics of close relationships and the ways in which cultural differences such as gender, the society we live in and our individual histories influence our expectations. The program also explores the relationship between a balance of power within a relationship and the long term success or failure of that relationship.

results.title: Geelong TCUFA : weaving and winding : more than a job : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Five employees of carpet manufacturer Brintons and Textile Clothing and Footwear Union tell about their lives before, during and after working at Brintons. The factory closed in June 2008, leaving 100 people without jobs.

results.title: Geelong and district : Moving memories 1911 - 1950s
results.creator_credit: National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: History comes alive with the rarely seen footage of Geelong and surrounding districts presented on this video. This compilation, selected from newsreels, documentaries, home movies and election propaganda. Featured are the towns of Geelong, Moriac, Queenscliff, Colac, Lorne and Corio. Highlights include: VFL Geelong vs Essendon 1911 ; WWI troops leaving Geelong ; Queenscliff 1923 ; construction of the Great Ocean Road 1920s ; Geelong centenary parade 1938 ; Miss Geelong 1945 ; Barwon floods 1951.

results.title: Geelong's m'name
results.creator_credit: Adrian Boddington, Geelong Harbor Trust Commissioners and Zanthus Films
results.brief_description: ‘The Geelong’ a tug boat in Corio Bay escorts cargo ships and tankers on the four hour journey along the deep but narrow channel into port. The tugs are on call day and night in the busy industrial port. All Geelong’s shipping activities are controlled by the signal station at Point Henry, site of the original settlement of Geelong. Crude oil from Persia, phosphate from Nauru, sulphur from Mexico, are among the cargoes brought to the port, while wool, wheat and meat, products from the rich Western district, are among its exports.
